It  is  the  policy of MECS Avon Plant management  to  commit  to
operating  the Avon Plant with the highest regard for the  safety
of  the  public, Plant personnel, and the environment. To  ensure
the  safety  of the public, Plant personnel, and the environment,
the  Plant  has  implemented  a  safety  management  system  that
includes the elements of the Federal Risk Management Program  for
Chemical  Accident Prevention (40CFR Part 68) program  applicable
to  Program  3  stationary sources. The policies  and  procedures
integrated   under   the   Plant's   safety   management   system
specifically  address  prevention of the  release  of  oleum  and
response to any accidental release of oleum.


1.1.2 Responsibilities


The  responsibilities for implementation of the safety policy are
as follows:

1.   Plant Manager - Has general responsibility for all personnel
and operation.

2.     Supervisor  -  Directly  accountable  for  the  safety  of
operations  under his control and the personal  safety  of  every
employee under his supervision.  He will establish safe operating
and  emergency procedures for his department.  He will  see  that
his  people  are  trained in these procedures and  in  plant-wide
safety  procedures and rules and will require adherence to  them.
He  will  not  permit operation of unsafe equipment and  start-up
projects implemented or process changes unless a thorough  review
is   done.   He  will  encourage  suggestions  to  imp

rove   safe
operations,  investigate all minor injuries,  and  be  alert  for
unsafe  conditions  and acts.  In addition, outside  of  his  own
area,  he  is  to take action to correct any unsafe practices  or
conditions which he notices.  Normally, this will mean calling to
the  attention of the Supervisor concerned.  However, where delay
of  action  may result in injury, he will take direct action  and
report later to the Supervisor concerned.

3.    Engineer  - Directly responsible for managing  project  and
process  change  that includes safety review  with  the  effected
personnel.   Also,  the engineer must utilize the  management  of
change  procedure for all reviews pertaining to changes - process
changes and projects.

4.    Individual Employee - Responsible for his own  safety,  for
learning  and  following safety regulations and safe  procedures,
for  detection and reporting of hazards and unsafe practices, and
to  take  action where action is necessary to prevent  injury  to
others.

5.    Health and Safety Forum - Purpose - To promote safe attitudes
 and practices both on and off the job. Function - communicate and 
collect employee input relative to the safety needs of the plant, 
select and provide general plant-wide safety programs and 
recommendations on policy and procedures.  (Coordinated by functional 
supervisors, usually in the form of a weekly meeting).

6.   Special Committees - Will be appointed to:
    Investigate and report on accidents or near misses.
    Conduct housekeeping and safety surveys.
    Conduct hazard reviews
    Conduct safety and operability reviews for projects, process
changes, and plant scale research test trials.
Or any other purpose best served by this means.

1.2  DESCRIPTION OF PROCESS, AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED  AT
     THE MECS AVON PLANT - OLEUM HANDLING SYSTEM
     
The  Tesoro  chemical plant supplies cool 25% oleum to  the  MECS
Avon  plant  by pumping it from an oleum storage tank  through  a
stainless  steel  pipeline.  The  pipeline  is  heat  traced  and
insulated. The cool incoming material is preheated in the line to
approximately  110oF and further in the oleum  cooler  before  it
flows into the oleum boiler by exchanging heat with hot, depleted
oleum.  Inside  the boiler, the oleum is heated  to  its  boiling
point  to  liberate sulfur trioxide which flows to  the  catalyst
sulfation  calciner. Weak (10% to 15%) hot oleum  overflows  back
through the oleum cooler, where it is cooled before being  pumped
back to the make-up tank at the Tesoro chemical plant.

Oleum is a cloudy, oily, dense liquid. It is also referred to  as
fuming sulfuric acid. Oleum is a solution of sulfur trioxide in
concentrated  sulfuric acid. Sulfur trioxide is  emitted  to  the
atmosphere upon release of oleum. The sulfur trioxide reacts with
moisture in air to

form a corrosive sulfuric acid mist. The toxic
endpoint  for oleum provided in Appendix A to 40 CFR Part  68  is
0.010 mg/I.



1.3  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The  accidental release prevention program at the MECS Avon Plant
consists  of  the following elements: Safety Information;  Hazard
Review;  Operating  Procedures; Training;  Mechanical  Integrity;
Management  of  Change;  Pre-Startup  Review;  Record  Retention;
Maintenance; Compliance Audits;  Incident Investigation; Employee
Participation;  Hot  Work  Permit, and Contractor  elements.  The
accidental release prevention program is referenced in the  Plant
Safety   Manual  which  documents  the  Plant's  existing  safety
management system. The policies and procedures that address  each
prevention  program element are part of the Plant Risk Management
Program.  The  policy and procedure documents address  activities
associated  with  planning,  implementation,  verification,   and
improvement.  The  purpose and scope of each element  is  briefly
described below.

1.3.1     Safety Information

The  plant  engineer maintains the Plant's Safety Information  to
ensure  that  safety  information related  to  oleum,  the  oleum
handling  process,  and  process  equipment  is  documented.  The
process  safety information documentation serves as a basis  from
which  any changes made by plant personnel can be evaluated  with
the  intent  to minimize the potential for a release and  improve
system operation reliability. The safety information consists of:
material  safety data sheet (MSDS) for oleum; block flow  diagram
of   the  process;  process  chemistry;  maximum  intended  oleum
inventory;  safe upper and lower temperatures, pressures,  flows,
and   compositions;  consequences  of  deviation;  materials   of
construction;  P&IDs;  equipment  specifications;  relief  system
design  and calculations; and codes and standards used to  design
and operate the oleum handling process. The Safety Information

is
updated  in the event of changes at the Plant. The Plant Engineer
identified  safety  information-related equipment  specifications
and  any  changes  needed for the system.  Ultimately  the  Plant
Manager   has   the  authority  to  approve  the  change   before
implementation.  The plant engineer prepares updates  if  changes
were  made. Adherence to applicable codes (e.g., ANSI 831.3, ASME
Section VIII) is documented in the Plant's Safety Information and
the  safety  information files are located in  the  process  file
drawer  for  the Oleum area. The file cabinet is located  in  the
Plant's Engineering Office Trailer.

1.3.2     Hazard Reviews

The purpose of the Plant's Management of Change procedure (PSB-17
Management  of Change) is to identify, evaluate and  control  the
hazards  involved with proposed changes to equipment,  chemicals,
or   procedures  used  in  plant  processes.  This  includes  RMP
regulated processes.

The  plant's  hazard  review approach is  incorporated  into  its
Management  of  Change  Procedure.  The  Plant's  Hazard   Review
procedure  addresses:  Hazard Review methodology;  Hazard  Review
scope; Hazard Review team composition; the system established  to
promptly  address  recommendations;  Hazard  Review  update   and
revalidation requirements; and Hazard Review worksheet retention.
The  July  15, 2002 Oleum System Hazard Review was completed  and
the  next one completed on February 7, 2008. The plant's bring-up
file  system  is  being  used  to alert  when  the  next  one  is
scheduled.  Recommendations identified in each HAZOP  review  and
revalidations  will be logged in the AR database  system  (Action
Request database system [based in MECS offices in St. Louis]) and
tracked to completion.


Oleum Process Hazard Analysis

The  most recent update for the process hazard analysis (PHA) for
the  oleum process was conducted on February 6 and 7, 2008.   The
initial PHA of the Oleum System was conducted on December 13  and
14,  199

5.  Previous revalidation of the initial PHA was reported
in  July  2002  and the February 2008 revalidation was  performed
based on an update policy of every 5 years.  The initial PHA  and
revalidations were performed according to the American  Institute
of   Chemical  Engineers  publication  Guidelines   for   Hazard
Evaluation Procedures, using the guideword HAZOP technique.  The
technique  was  originally developed for application  to  process
plants,  and  is therefore appropriate for the PHA of  the  Oleum
System.   To prepare for this revalidation the revalidation  team
considered  the  five  year  accident history  concerning  oleum,
process   changes   over  the  last  five  years   and   previous
recommendations from the July 2002 PHA.

The  February  2008  PHA  for  oleum  was  performed  by  a  team
consisting of the company technology manager, the plant  manager,
the   plant  engineer,  and  senior  maintenance  and  operations
personnel.   The PHA revalidation team performed a complete HAZOP
assessment  using an expanded list of parameters  and  guidewords
resulting  in  multiple  combinations.  The  team  assessed  non-
standard procedures such as purging and maintenance shutdowns for
potentials  hazards and operability issues.  The  team  revisited
the  prior  HAZOP including safeguards to determine if they  were
still  in  use and adequate for the intention and the  status  of
prior  recommendations.  Additions and changes were reviewed  and
any accidents over the past five years were considered.

The team revalidated the prior PHA and found the safeguards to be
in  use  and  working.   The  previous recommendations  had  been
further  evaluated and implemented if appropriate.  The  February
2008 PHA for oleum resulted in the following recommendations:

  1.   Observe the valving and pump status when requesting  purge
     fluid from Tesoro, to assure the proper purge fluid is being
     supplied.
     
  2. A  torque  checklist is recommended as

a standard  procedure
     during  system maintenance for the maintenance personnel  to
     use to sign off that the torquing has been completed.
     
  3.   Placement of a three-way valve in the compressed air  line
     supplying the low volume and high volume purge meters to the
     level and pressure transmitter gas side impulse line.   This
     would  make even less likely any failure to purge the boiler
     and SO3 feed line with air during the acid spray operation.
     
   4.   Indicate both the low and high volume purge meters  on  a
     revised   P&ID.   Other  improvements  to  the   PI&D   were
     discussed.
     
  5.   Test the thickness of the SO3 feed line to the calciner as
     part   of  set  of  practices  for  non-destructive  testing
     evaluation  of  oleum system documented  in  SOP-XI-H  Oleum
     System Design Fabrication and Maintenance (NDT program).
     
  6. For  the  acid  spray  system, check for  an  adequate  pump
     pressure   rating,   pressure  relief  rating,   and   valve
     configuration  within the acid spray system  to  avoid  mis-
     operation.
     
  7.     Schedule  to perform a thickness test on the acid  spray
     line  after so many hours of operation as part of  the  non-
     destructive testing (NDT) program.  Acid spray operation  is
     intermittent but a log shall be kept and when operating time
     is  approaching the inspection period, the  line  is  to  be
     added into the testing program.
     
The  seven  new  recommendations will be addressed in  accordance
with  the  Plant's PHA procedure which includes a  more  detailed
analysis of each recommendation.

External Events
External   events   included  in  the   Hazard   Review   include
earthquakes, fires, and power failures. Human error was addressed
in  the  Hazard  Review as a cause of hazards, as  was  equipment
malfunction.  Revalidations will be conducted in accordance  with
the  Federal OSHA Standards Interpretation and Compli

ance  Letter
entitled  Steps  for Updating and Revalidating a  Process  Hazard
Analysis (PHA), dated January 22, 1998.

The  MECS  Avon  Plant  does  not lie  within  an  Alquist-Priolo
Earthquake Fault Zone, as delineated by the Division of Mines and
Geology. The Avon Plant to be approximately 0.4 mile east of  the
Concord  -  Green Valley fault. The soils at the Avon Plant  site
are  not  known  to be prone to liquefaction, fault  rupture,  or
landslides. Ground shaking is the greatest risk in the  event  of
an earthquake.

In  1997, a facility-wide seismic assessment was performed.  This
facility-wide assessment included the Oleum Handling system.  The
purpose  of  the  seismic review was to identify and  modify  all
structural  components that might need seismic  strengthening  so
that accidental releases of oleum due to seismic events could  be
prevented.  A  list  of  design upgrade recommendations  was  put
together  by  the  seismic consultant. All of the recommendations
related  to the Oleum Handling system have been implemented.  The
Oleum Handling system (including all equipment, associated piping
and  bracing)  was upgraded in accordance with applicable  codes,
standards  and  guidelines  as they pertain  to  Zone  4  seismic
restraints  and/or performance in accordance with the  1997  UBC.
The  standards used for the design recommendations were the  1997
Uniform  Building Code, and the S2 rating for Business Security
and Life Safety from the FEMA 273 Guidelines.   The oleum seismic
assessment was revalidated in 2004.

1.3.3     Operating Procedures

The  purpose  of the Operating Procedures element of the  Plant's
Release  Prevention Program is to provide a method for developing
and  implementing  written  operating procedures  to  give  clear
instructions for safely conducting activities associated with the
Plant's  oleum handling system. The Operating Procedures  element
of  the Plant's Release Prevention Program addresses: development
and   impleme

ntation  of  written  procedures  to  provide  clear
instructions for safely conducting activities associated with the
Plant's oleum handling system; documentation of process operating
limits,  of the consequences of deviating from those limits,  and
of   the   steps  necessary  to  correct  or  avoid   deviations;
documentation  of  process safety and health considerations;  and
requirements  for  periodic review of operating  procedures.  The
original operating procedures for the oleum system were developed
by the stationary source. They have been revised based on changes
to  the  system since the original installation. The most  recent
revisions were made in February 2008.

The  Operations  Supervisor  will  initiate  operating  procedure
reviews at least triennially, but also as necessitated by changes
to the oleum handling system. The Operations Supervisor maintains
the  operating  procedures and these are located in  the  plant's
standard  operating  folder in the ISO documents  folder  on  the
plant file server. Working (paper) copies are printed as needed.

1.3.4     Training

The  purpose  of the Plant's Training procedure (HMM-12  Training
Procedure) is to ensure that personnel involved in operating  the
Plant's  oleum  handling  systems have  received  and  understood
training  in  the operating procedures required by the  Operating
Procedures element of the Plant's Release Prevention Program. The
Training  Procedure  addresses:  initial  training  requirements;
refresher  training requirements; and documentation  of  employee
training.  Initial training includes both written instruction  on
each  operating  procedure  and  on-the-job  training  under  the
supervision  of an experienced Technician. Refresher training  is
provided triennially and this training consists of reviewing  the
existing  operating procedures and class room. Operator  training
is  also  administered prior to the implementation of changes  to
the oleum handling system. Training reco

rds document the name  of
the employee receiving the training, the content of the training,
the  date  the  training was administered, and the  name  of  the
trainer.   Verifying  competency  consists  of  input  from   the
experience  technicians  and written testing.  Employee  training
records  including written certification for those  who  operated
the  system before 6/22/03 are retained permanently. The Training
element is also included in the Management of Change Procedure by
reference for use on any plant system.

Maintenance   employees,   including  direct   managed   contract
employees, participate in the plant safety training such as  lock
out,  pipeline  break-in, intra-company  permit,  and  unplugging
oleum  lines. A sign-in sheet is used to verify attendance and  a
question answer session is conducted to verify understanding  and
the  verification  of understanding method is documented  in  the
sign-in sheet.


1.3.5     Mechanical Integrity

The  following  elements that ensure oleum  system  integrity  is
maintained are in place and include: documentation of  codes  and
standards used to verify system design and construction, material
and  fabrication  control of new fabrications and  installations,
joint assembly procedures to ensure high system integrity, annual
relief  system maintenance that includes rupture disc and  relief
valve  replacement  and  valve  testing,  regular  periodic  non-
destructive testing (NDT) of pipelines and equipment to determine
material   thickness  loss,   predictive  replacement  of   these
elements as material thins, and retention of fabrication and test
X-ray films for comparison with later tests.


1.3.6     Management of Change

The Plant's Management of Change Procedure (PSB-17 Management  of
Change)  is  intended to insure adequate safety and environmental
review   prior  to  changes  in  process  equipment,   chemicals,
instruments,  or  interlocks  or  in  the  tools,   methods,   or
procedures  used  to per

form any job.  In order  to  ensure  that
changes  do  not  introduce new safety hazards and  environmental
problems,  the following procedures will be used, as appropriate,
to manage changes in process, chemicals used, tools, methods, and
equipment  prior  to  making the change: 1) Hazard  Analysis,  2)
Project Reviews, 3) New Chemical Use Approval, 4) Process  Safety
Audit,  5)  Operating Procedures and Training, and 6) Job  Safety
Analyses.   First  implemented in 1991 this  procedure  has  been
broadly used and involves participation form both staff and plant
workers,  employees and contract, in an effort to anticipate  and
resolve any potential safety concerns presented by a change.


1.3.7 Pre-Startup Review

For  new  sources or modified sources as noted above  in  section
1.4.6  and  as  described in project management procedure  PMP-02
Project Reviews. Pre-startup review includes confirming that  new
or    modified    construction   or   equipment   meets    design
specifications,  ensuring procedures for safety  and  emergencies
are in place, performance of a PHA, and ensuring proper training.

1.3.8     Record Retention Policy

All  records associated with the prevention program elements  are
retained  for  five  years, unless otherwise  specified  by  MECS
record  retention policy. The record retention policy is  company
confidential.

1.3.9     Maintenance

The purpose of the MM-08 Avon Maintenance Program is to establish
the  requirements for daily inspection and maintenance  of  plant
equipment. The program includes procedures and practices specific
to  the  oleum handling system that are included in either  plant
operating  instructions or safety bulletins. One purpose  of  the
Maintenance Program is to ensure that process equipment  used  to
handle  oleum  is maintained to minimize the risk  of  accidental
release.

Practices  in  place  for maintenance and to maintain  mechanical
integrity  with regard to the oleum system include: documentation
of

codes  and  standards  used  to  verify  system  design  and
construction,   material   and   fabrication   control   of   new
fabrications  and  installations, joint  assembly  procedures  to
ensure  high  system integrity, annual relief system  maintenance
that includes rupture disc and relief valve replacement and valve
testing,  regular  periodic  non-destructive  testing  (NDT)   of
pipelines  and  equipment to determine material  thickness  loss,
predictive  replacement of these elements as material thins,  and
retention of fabrication and test X-ray films for comparison with
later tests.

The Maintenance policy addresses the following activities as they
relate  to  the  oleum  handling system: training  on  the  oleum
handling  system  and  its hazards, safe conduct  of  maintenance
activities;  inspection and testing; and correcting  deficiencies
in  equipment.   The  last field verification  of  the  equipment
installation was in 12/07 as part of the plant shutdown for  turn
around.

The maintenance procedures consist of dismantling and putting the
system  back  into service and these procedures  resides  in  the
Engineering Office Trailer. The Plant uses the following  as  the
basis of the scope, nature, and frequency of inspection, testing,
and  maintenance activities: ANSI B31.3 for piping; ASME  Section
VIII  for  unfired pressure vessels such as the oleum boiler  and
oleum  cooler;  and manufacturers' recommendations  for  specific
equipment  such  as magnetic drive pumps. The  tests  consist  of
using  Ultra  Sonic, UST for monitoring boiler  and  piping  wall
thickness,   and  x-ray  for  weld  condition.  Identifying   and
correcting deficiencies is done in accordance with manufacturers'
specifications  and  Plant specifications.  Individuals  who  are
involved  in  fabricating the piping have to take a welding  test
and passing it is required before work. The welds are x-rayed and
the  standard, 831.3 requires x-raying 10% of the welds. However,

the  number of welds produced is low enough that 100% are tested.
The materials used for oleum service must originate from American
made  sources, since the quality from foreign made  sources  have
been inconsistent. Maintenance program documents and records  are
subject to triennial audit, and program documents are revised  as
necessary.

Maintenance equipment records are kept in the maintenance office.
Repair requests (repair orders) are entered into the computerized
maintenance  management  system by the  contract  records  clerk.
Originals  are  filed in the main office pending questions  about
the repair.

1.3.10    Compliance Audits

The  purpose of the Plant's HMM-13 Audit Policy and Procedure  is
to establish the requirements for conducting compliance audits in
accordance  with the RMP, as described in 40 CFR  68.79  (Program
3).  The  purpose  of such compliance audits  is  to  verify  the
effectiveness  of  the Plant's Prevention Programs.  The  Plant's
Compliance  Audit  procedure requires  triennial  review  of  the
Plant's Prevention Program procedure documents, and evaluation of
the  implementation  of  these procedures by  conducting  records
reviews, employee interviews, and field inspections. The  Plant's
Compliance Audit procedure also requires that recommendations  be
formulated  to resolve any identified deficiencies.  The  Plant's
Compliance  Audits  procedure  addresses:  pre-audit  activities;
conduct  of  the Prevention Program compliance audit;  and  post-
audit  activities,  including  reporting  and  taking  action  to
resolve  any  identified deficiencies. The team  responsible  for
conducting  Compliance  Audits  will  consist  of  at  least  one
individual  with knowledge of the oleum handling system  and  one
individual,  an  outside consultant, with knowledge  of  auditing
techniques.  Audit  recommendations will  be  logged  in  the  AR
database  (Action Request database system [based in MECS  offices
in  St.  Louis])  and  tracked m

onthly until  they  are  reported
complete  in  the Plant's Audit Recommendation Follow-up  Report.
Copies  of  the  Audit Recommendation Follow-up  Report  will  be
routed  to  the  Plant  Manager for monthly review  and  ultimate
approval.

1.3.11    Incident Investigation

The   purpose   of  the  Plant's  PSB-25  Accident  Investigation
Procedure  is  to provide a method for reporting,  investigating,
and  preventing reoccurrence of incidents that result in or could
reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of oleum.  The
Plant's  Incident Investigation procedure addresses: 1)  internal
reporting  of  incidents;  2)  the procedure  for  initiating  an
incident  investigation;  3)  the establishment  of  an  Incident
Investigation  Team, and requirements for the selection  of  Team
members;  4)  investigating the incident; 5) preparation  of  the
Incident Investigation Report and the minimum requirements of the
Report; 6) the system established to promptly address and resolve
the  report  findings and recommendations; and 7) the method  for
reviewing  the  findings of the Incident Investigation  with  all
operating,  maintenance, and other affected personnel  (including
contract  employees) whose work assignments are relevant  to  the
findings. A copy of the incident investigation report is provided
to  Contra  Costa  Health  Services. The  Incident  Investigation
procedure  applies to all incidents and near misses at the  Plant
with  the  potential for catastrophic release of oleum.  Incident
investigations  will  be  initiated  within  48  hours.  Incident
investigation  reports will include: the date  and  time  of  the
incident;   the  date  and  time  the  investigation   began;   a
description  of  the  incident;  factors  contributing   to   the
incident;  recommendations resulting from the investigation;  and
approval  by  the  Plant  Manager. Recommendations  arising  from
incident investigations will be logged and tracked monthly  until
they  a

re completed.  Incident investigations are tracked in  the
AR database system.

1.3.12    Employee Participation

The  plant  has  actively  practiced  employee  participation  in

1.5  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

MECS  Inc.'s  approach to protecting personnel  in  the  unlikely
event of an oleum release is embodied in the Avon plant Emergency
Plan (ESH-02 Emergency Plan), developed in accordance with 29 CFR
1910.38, for the protection of individuals onsite.

The  purpose  of the Emergency Plan is to ensure that individuals
(classified as specialist employees under HazWOPER) at  the  MECS
Avon  Plant  are  safely sheltered in-place or evacuated  in  the
event  of  an emergency that requires that people take protective
action.    Examples  of  emergencies  that  may  require   taking
protective  action include: an uncontrolled release of  oleum;  a
structure  fire;  or a severe earthquake.  The Plant's  Emergency
Plan addresses all of the following:
    Recognizing and reporting emergencies;
    Emergency shelter/escape procedures, emergency shelter
assignments, and emergency escape route assignments;
    Procedures to be followed by personnel who safely shut down
critical plant operations before evacuating;
    Procedure to account for employees, contractors, and
visitors after they have sheltered in-place or evacuated;
    Rescue and medical duties for personnel assigned to perform
them;
    Designation of individuals who can be contacted for further
information about the Emergency Plan; and
    Training requirements.

The  Emergency  Plan  is  audited  triennially  and  revised   as
necessary.    The  Emergency  Plan  will  also  be   revised   as
necessitated by changes to the Plant.

The plant also has a procedure to notify industrial neighbors and
regulatory  agencies.  This procedure ensures that the  necessary
requests  for emergency assistance are made in rapid and  orderly
fashion, in the event of any emergency, including an uncontrolled
release  of  oleum.  The procedure incorporates the Contra  Costa

1.6  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

There  are  currently  several  outstanding  recommendations  for

Analysis.  Chief among these was the reduction of oleum inventory

formulated  during the initial and subsequent  Hazard  Review  of

In  addition  to  the  Plant's management system  and  Prevention
Program elements, the design of the Plant's oleum handling system
incorporates  several features to prevent or mitigate  accidental
releases of oleum:

       The Oleum Boiler is located on a curbed, paved containment
       pad to limit the surface area of a spill. The intent for this
       safeguard is to provide an intrinsically safe system to capture
       and contain an oleum release. This safeguard was implemented in
       1993 as part of the effort to comply with Uniform Fire Code 80
       for hazardous materials.
       
       The pad is sloped to a drain designed to drain the contents
       of the Oleum Boiler in about 1 1/2 minutes - Implemented in 1993
      
       Oleum is drained to a water-filled sump, where  oleum
       combines  with water to form non-fuming sulfuric  acid  -
       implemented in 1993
       
       Oleum is handled in magnetic drive pumps to eliminate seal
       leakage - implemented in 1994 with continued improvements in 1998
       for more reliable magnetic drive pumps
       
       All relief valves discharge into closed systems. The intent
       is to prevent oleum spray outs through a flanged connection from
       hydro - stat pressure condition and the two relief valves, one
       for incoming and return, were installed in 1991.
